title: Japan's Economy Hits the Skids-and Things Are Likely to Get Worse
summary: U.S.-China trade dispute and Tokyo's frictions with South Korea weighed on Japanese exports. TOKYO-Japan's economy grew at the slowest pace in a year as the U.S.-China trade dispute and Tokyo's frictions with South Korea weighed on exports.

title: Latest Chinese Numbers Show Economy Dragging
summary: Industrial output, household consumption and fixed-asset investment all slowed in October, missing forecasts. BEIJING-China's economy is showing fresh signs of weakness even as inflation continues to tick higher-a conundrum for policy makers as the trade dispute with the U.S. drags on.

title: Icahn Backs Xerox's Big Bid, Reveals Stake in Target HP
summary: Activist investor says he has 4.24% stake in HP. Activist investor Carl Icahn is pushing for the proposed union of Xerox Holdings Corp. and HP Inc., arguing that a combination of the printer makers could yield big profits for investors.

title: Appeals Court Rebuffs Renewed Trump Bid to Block House Subpoena for Financial Records
summary: Court order sets stage for emergency appeal to the Supreme Court. WASHINGTON-A federal appeals court on Wednesday refused to reconsider a ruling that allowed a House committee to subpoena President Trump's financial records from his longtime accounting firm, a move that gives the president a week to seek emergency intervention from the Supreme Court.

title: Alibaba Seeks to Raise $13 Billion in Hong Kong Share Sale
summary: Chinese online retailer's secondary listing likely to take place in second half of November. BEIJING- Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. 's leaders used the code "Project Orange" to discuss the company's blockbuster initial public offering in 2014. Now they are close to seeing the fruition of "Project Tangerine," the internal name for their effort to raise roughly $13 billion in a secondary listing in Hong Kong.

title: Smith & Wesson Parent Plans Split
summary: Transaction would be done in the second half of 2020; company cites changes in political climate and economic, investing and insurance markets. The maker of Smith & Wesson firearms said it would split into two companies and reverse a multiyear diversification effort aimed at countering the sluggish domestic gun business.

title: Barr Unveils Plan to Combat Gun Violence
summary: Plan, which focuses on bolstering background checks, offers few new ideas. A Justice Department plan to combat gun violence aims to improve background checks by encouraging federal prosecutors to more quickly contribute information about people whose mental-health history prevents them from owning firearms.

title: Yahoo Japan in Talks Over Combining With Chat App Line
summary: SoftBank effectively controls Yahoo Japan through subsidiaries, while South Korea-based Naver controls Line. TOKYO-Two of Japan's internet leaders-news and shopping site Yahoo Japan and chat app Line-are in talks over a combination that could expand SoftBank Group Corp.'s empire, the companies said Thursday.

title: Impeachment Inquiry: Public Hearing Surfaces New Claim on Trump
summary: Top envoy in Ukraine says president asked about status of possible investigations. WASHINGTON-President Trump in a summer phone call asked about politically advantageous investigations he wanted the Ukrainian president to announce, the top U.S. diplomat in Ukraine disclosed Wednesday as the House opened the public phase of its seven-week-old impeachment probe.

title: Cisco Projects Reduced Revenue in Current Quarter
summary: Company blames pause in customer spending tied to political and economic concern. Cisco Systems Inc., the networking-equipment giant, projected its first quarterly revenue decline in more than two years, blaming what it called a pause in customer spending given political and economic apprehension.

title: Fed's Harker: It's Now Time for Fed to Hold Steady on Rates
summary: 'We should hold steady for a while and watch how things unfold,' the Philadelphia Fed president says. Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker reiterated that he has opposed the central bank's rate cuts this year.

title: Trump-Erdogan Talks See Little Progress
summary: Mr. Trump said he was 'big fan' of Turkish leader, who called for new chapter in relations between two countries. A long-awaited meeting between President Trump and Turkey's leader ended Wednesday without a resolution of key issues on which the two sides have been divided, including Ankara's purchase of a Russian air-defense system and the U.S. partnership with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces.

title: A Year After Amazon Scrapped HQ2 Plan, New York Residents Get a Say
summary: Resume Subscription. A year ago a swath of waterfront in Long Island City, Queens, was at the center of one of the biggest economic development deals in the nation, with Amazon.com Inc. choosing it as the location for a new campus.

title: WeWork's Loss Balloons to $1.25 Billion
summary: Office space startup's expenses in latest quarter far outpace the 94% jump in revenue. Office-space startup WeWork lost $1.25 billion in the third quarter as expenses far outpaced revenue growth, draining the company's cash ahead of a bailout by SoftBank Group Corp. last month.

title: Fewer New York City Children Show Elevated Lead Levels
summary: Nearly 2,000 children in the city still had elevated lead levels, despite city's push to cut exposure. New York City has seen a slight decrease this year in the number of children with elevated blood-lead levels, city officials said Wednesday.

title: The Banality of Impeachment
summary: The hearings are a pro-forma march to a foregone conclusion.. House Democrats went public Wednesday with what the media are calling "historic" impeachment hearings, but what strikes us is the pre-cooked nature of the exercise. This isn't a search for truth. It's a set-piece production to promote a foregone conclusion. Democrats are turning impeachment into another partisan banality, and the country won't be better for it.

title: Socialist Against Confiscation
summary: Bernie Sanders says a mandatory gun buyback 'is unconstitutional.'. Bernie Sanders, believe it or not, is standing up for American property rights-at least when it comes to guns. Asked at a rally Sunday in Iowa whether he supports "mandatory buybacks for AR-15s and AK-47s," Mr. Sanders didn't equivocate in the slightest.

title: Washington's Affirmative Repudiation
summary: State voters reject racial preferences, but Seattle rebuffs Amazon.. Support in polls for racial preferences varies wildly depending how the issue is framed. Yet when racial-preference systems have been put directly to voters in statewide referendums with real consequences, majorities have almost always said no. Last week Washington state's liberal electorate continued that trend, narrowly overruling the Legislature's bid to reintroduce preferences in public education and employment.

title: Facebook Reports Gains in Removing Objectionable Content
summary: Company says disclosure of statistics also shows its commitment to transparency. Facebook Inc. reported gains in detecting hate speech, child-abuse imagery and terrorist propaganda on its platforms, arguing that its willingness to publish statistics on the removal of objectionable content shows its commitment to transparency.

title: Bolivia's Caretaker President Calls New Elections
summary: Former senate vice president Jeanine Añez appoints new army chief; supporters of ex-leader Morales vow to hold protests until he returns to power. LA PAZ, Bolivia-On her first day as Bolivia's caretaker president, Jeanine Añez appointed a new army chief and proposed new elections, moving to fill a power vacuum amid protests by supporters of exiled former President Evo Morales.

title: Outside the Hearing Room, a Carnival
summary: Historic session draws politics junkies, a self-described drag queen-and therapy dogs. The atmosphere at the U.S. Capitol was part sober ceremony, part political carnival as the House's impeachment inquiry held its first public hearing on Wednesday.

title: Slack and Microsoft Have a Symbiotic Relationship
summary: Slack uses Microsoft's open-source software to make its collaboration tool work seamlessly with parts of Office 365. Microsoft Corp. and Slack Technologies Inc. are competing for a piece of the workplace-collaboration market, but behind the scenes, the companies are doing some collaborating of their own.

title: Switching Schools Shouldn't Be the Hard Part for Military Families
summary: Education savings accounts would help service members spare their kids from a tough start after every move.. When a military service member is recognized at a retirement or award ceremony, it's almost obligatory also to recognize the husband or wife and family whose support made that honored service possible. While these tributes may sound like mere courtesy, to the military families listening it is all too poignant. While a service member in today's U.S. military is a volunteer, the families have been "drafted" to serve, whether they want to or not. The risk of death or injury-even noncombat service can be dangerous-is borne not only by service members but their loved ones as well.

title: Five Moments That Mattered in the Impeachment Hearing
summary: A new claim emerges as Democrats and Republicans take their lanes in the first day of public hearings. Wednesday's impeachment hearing featuring testimony from two career diplomats offered a significant new revelation and several insights into the circumstances surrounding President Trump's July 25 call with then newly inaugurated Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. The hearing also offered a taste of how Democrats and Republicans intend to proceed now that the inquiry has shifted into its public phase.

title: The Take Down Trump Project
summary: Once the Adam Schiff show shuts down, voters will have 10 months to decide if it has been worth the trouble.. Nancy Pelosi was right the first time. The Democrats shouldn't have done this. They should not have tried to make the already overwhelmed American public believe that Donald Trump's umpteenth "norms" violation was a constitutional crisis. But no, the party's leftmost elements insisted, and the Beltway press insisted. Mr. Trump had to be impeached.

title: Impeachment Becomes a Pratfall Comedy
summary: Democrats didn't care when Obama opposed military aid to Ukraine. Now it's an impeachable offense.. As the impeachment hearings kick off, Democrats put on a jarring display of rhetorical whiplash, saying one thing this time but something remarkably different the next. Politicians are often inconsistent, but this is ridiculous.

title: No Country for Old Presidents
summary: Biden or Bloomberg would be older at the end of his term than Nixon when he died.. Should there be an upper age limit on the presidency? Former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, 77, may join a crowded and aging field of candidates. Last month Bernie Sanders, 78, was hospitalized with what the campaign called "chest discomfort" and turned out to be a heart attack. In September 2016, Hillary Clinton, then 68, was privately diagnosed with pneumonia. The campaign concealed the diagnosis until she was caught on camera fainting from dehydration.

title: 'Golden Rice' Review: Against the Grain
summary: An estimated one million people-mostly children-die annually from vitamin-A deﬁciency. Golden rice could reverse that.. Why has it taken more than two decades to develop "golden rice," the genetically modified crop that promises to save millions of lives? The many delays have been costly. Every year an estimated one million people, mostly children, die, and another half a million more lose their eyesight, from vitamin-A deficiency. Golden rice-with its yellow grains rich in beta carotene, which the human body turns into vitamin A-could virtually eliminate this problem in countries where rice is the staple food.

title: SoCal Edison Agrees to Settlement in 2017, 2018 Wildfires
summary: The $360 million plan follows PG&E's $1 billion compensation agreement for Northern California wildfires. California's second-largest utility company has agreed to pay $360 million to compensate about two dozen local governmental entities for damages and other costs related to a series of fires and resulting mudslides that hit the region in 2017 and 2018.

title: Bond Investors Bet On Rise in Inflation
summary: Market-based measures of inflation expectations have climbed in recent weeks. Bond investors are betting inflation is making a comeback.

title: Mike Henry to Become BHP Group CEO in January
summary: Andrew Mackenzie will retire after six years, company says. MELBOURNE, Australia- BHP Group Ltd. named Mike Henry as its new chief executive, opting for his experience running the most profitable operation of the global miner after a tumultuous period of big swings in commodity prices and exiting legacy assets.

title: Homespun Firms Challenge Wall Street's Muni-Bond Supremacy
summary: The SEC is considering allowing advisers to arrange sales to skilled investors without the involvement of large banks and midsize brokers. Wall Street's longstanding hold on the $4 trillion municipal-bond market faces a challenge from an onslaught of small, independent firms known as municipal advisers.

title: Prosecutors Call Stone a Chronic Liar. His Defense Says, 'So What?'
summary: 'He lied over and over and over again,' government says of former Trump adviser as jury prepares to deliberate. A federal jury is set to begin deliberating Thursday morning over whether former Trump adviser Roger Stone lied to Congress, after a one-week trial that included testimony from several Trump campaign officials, hundreds of vulgar text messages and many references to "The Godfather."

title: Resignation at GitLab Highlights Concerns Over Corporate Espionage
summary: The former compliance director at the San Francisco-based tech company resigned after objecting to a ban on hiring employees in Russia and China. The recent resignation of a compliance director at GitLab Inc. illustrates anxiety in the tech industry about foreign espionage. It also shows how, in managing one risk, companies can expose themselves to other risks.

title: Treat China as the Nuclear Superpower It Is
summary: If Beijing really has only a tiny number of warheads, why are they housed in a 3,000-mile tunnel system?. Doubtless the president would not be delighted by the likening of his administration to a giant fat guy who has never skied, pushing off from the top of a double-black-diamond slope and on his way down taking out flags, trees, and people. And yet somehow amid the chaos and ceaseless acceleration quite a few things have been done right. One of them, invisible to and above the horizons of the lacquered info-babes and mouth-breathing morons who inhabit cable news, is that unlike previous, negligent administrations of both parties, this one has addressed the need to bring China into a nuclear arms-control regime.

title: Three Tales of a City: Bloomberg, de Blasio and Trump
summary: Each New York politician in his own way represents a facet of the Big Apple's multiple personalities.. Bill de Blasio, New York's left-wing mayor, has suspended his presidential campaign. Michael Bloomberg, the billionaire ex-mayor, is thinking of plunging into the presidential race, on the calculation that none of the present Democratic candidates seem sufficiently "well positioned" to defeat President Trump. And Mr. Trump-a New Yorker if ever there was one-has filed paperwork to change his legal residence from the Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue to Mar-a-Lago, his Xanadu in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Deval Patrick Has Decided to Enter Democratic Presidential Race
summary: Former Massachusetts governor had ruled out a presidential run last year. Former Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick has decided to make a late entry into the crowded 2020 Democratic presidential primary field, telling people close to him that he will run, according to people familiar with the conversations.

title: Disney Reports 10 Million Users for Its New Disney+ Streaming Service
summary: The company had been offering subscriptions to Disney+ for several months before Tuesday's launch. LOS ANGELES- Walt Disney Co. 's flagship streaming service has signed up 10 million users, the company said the day after Disney+ launched.

title: Bishop Investigating Abuse in Buffalo Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct
summary: An attorney for the accuser said his client was abused by Bishop Nicholas DiMarzio starting in 1974. The bishop tasked with investigating the handling of clergy abuse allegations in Buffalo, N.Y., has himself been accused of abusing a young boy.

title: Turkey Gathered Information in the U.S. Against Its Critics
summary: U.S. law firm compiled reports that Turkish Embassy forwarded to prosecutors; one target fears consequences for relatives. WASHINGTON-Turkey's government used a Washington law firm to gather information about its critics, including residents of the U.S., who it believed were allied with a movement that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan regards as a central enemy, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Wealth Taxes, Incentives and 'Free' Benefits
summary: The Democratic senators' proposals will quickly run out of billionaires and millionaires to tax.. Regarding your editorial "Where Wealth Taxes Failed" (Nov. 5): One major difference between European countries and the U.S. is that the top marginal tax rate is already much higher in the European countries you cite. A wealth tax in a country like Sweden, with a 57% marginal tax rate, isn't comparable to a country like the U.S., with a 37% maximum rate.

title: Humansplaining Explained
summary: Actually, the problem Is 'humansplaining'. I might be wrong, but I think Colin Fleming just humansplained humansplaining ("Actually, the Problem Is 'Humansplaining,'" op-ed, Nov. 4).

title: McClatchy Seeks to Have U.S. Take Over Pension Fund
summary: Nation's third-largest newspaper publisher said its pension fund has a $535 million shortfall, straining its liquidity. McClatchy Co. , the third-largest newspaper publisher in the U.S. by circulation, said it has begun talks with its creditors and federal authorities about a possible government takeover of its pension fund as it tries to relieve considerable liquidity pressure due to its pension responsibilities and debt load.

title: Impeachment Hearings Emphasize Rift in Americans' Views
summary: Some watched, others avoided witness testimony on President Trump's interactions with Ukraine. Some Americans watched carefully on the first day of public hearings in the House impeachment inquiry, eager to hear testimony for themselves, while others chose not to watch what they considered a theatrical display.

title: Dow, S&P 500 End at Records Again
summary: The indexes advance as investors parse headlines on trade talks, interest-rate policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced Wednesday as investors parsed the latest headlines on U.S-Chinese trade talks and Federal Reserve interest-rate policy.

title: Energizer's Stronger Fourth-Quarter Results Send Its Shares Up 15%
summary: The company expects total sales to increase between 9% and 10% for its 2020 fiscal year. Shares of Energizer Holdings Inc. surged after the battery manufacturer reported higher-than-anticipated quarterly sales.

title: The Bryan Brothers Plan to Retire From Tennis in 2020
summary: Bob and Mike, who have won 16 major doubles titles together, plan to end their careers after next year's U.S. Open. When Bob and Mike Bryan won their first Grand Slam doubles title in Paris in 2003, they were 25 years old. Back then, they hoped they would last until age 34 and then retire.

title: Lagging Retail Stocks Will Soon Face Next Big Test
summary: Department stores, clothing retailers have trailed behind the broader stock market. Friday is shaping up to be a big day for retail stocks.

title: iPad Pseudo-Tax Money Is Ingenious Progressive Coup
summary: I need to consider when I shell out $900 for my next iPhone that I will be paying a tax to subsidize the amelioration of convoluted reasoning in California that creates most of its problems.. Your editorial "Affordable Rents at the iPad" (Nov. 6) describes the billions of dollars Apple and other big California tech giants are contributing to increase availability of "affordable housing" in the Silicon Valley area. So now I need to consider when I shell out $900 for my next iPhone that I will be paying a tax to subsidize the amelioration of convoluted reasoning in California that creates most of its problems. That system has invented a new concept: a free-market tax-collection mechanism for a muddled progressive state that manages to dredge in revenues from around the country and world.

title: Drug Prices Aren't Too Low for Americans
summary: Even if Medicaid and 340B discounts applied to the drugs in shortage, those discounts represent a very small part of overall drug spending and are unlikely to have a measurable impact on manufacturer decisions on how much of a drug to make.. David R. Henderson and Charles L. Hooper claim that drug discount programs like Medicaid's "best price" and the 340B Drug Pricing Program drive prices down to a point where manufacturers are no longer willing to produce a drug ("Sometimes Drug Prices Are Too Low," Nov. 1). Yet the majority of drug shortages involve generic injectable medications used mainly in inpatient settings where these outpatient drug discount programs don't apply. A recent report by the FDA found more than 60% of shortages are caused by manufacturing or quality problems.

title: United Airlines' Costs Rise Amid 737 MAX Grounding, CFO Says
summary: The U.S. airline, which has had to cancel flights and use less-efficient jets, isn't in a rush to settle with Boeing, United CFO Gerry Laderman says. United Airlines Holdings Inc. has experienced a double-digit increase in operating costs on certain routes because of the continued grounding of Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX aircraft, the airline's finance chief said.

title: As Hong Kong Universities Become Battle Zones, Mainland Chinese Students Flee
summary: Some Chinese students are worried about their safety as tensions escalate and protesters clash with police on campus. Hundreds of mainland Chinese students fled across Hong Kong's border into Shenzhen on Wednesday, seeking temporary shelter in hostels, hotels and relatives' homes after days of heightened violence on several university campuses in the city.

title: Why Falling Rates Haven't Sunk the Banks
summary: Investors are bidding up bank shares hoping that a small decline in deposit costs is a taste of things to come. When it comes to bank stocks, there is a lot riding on deposits.

title: Comcast Argues High Court Should Quash Discrimination Suit
summary: Television producer and personality Byron Allen alleges company rejected his channels due to race. WASHINGTON- Comcast Corp. , seeking to quash a discrimination suit filed by a black television producer, faced a skeptical Supreme Court at Wednesday arguments, where several justices suggested there was enough in Byron Allen's allegations to get his case into court.

title: U.S. Senate Stares Down Olympic Officials
summary: Lawmakers accused the U.S. Olympic Committee of being disingenuous and voted to advance legislation tightening Congress' grip over it. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee told Congress that tightening federal control over the committee's leaders in the wake of sex abuse scandals risked Team USA athletes being barred from future Olympic Games.

title: Updating the Menu at the Airport
summary: Dining options are getting livelier, as airports add food halls with local fare-but also cater to travelers who favor national chains.. Food in airports has become more appetizing in recent years. But hungry travelers still favor burgers and pizza from national chains over local artisanal offerings.

title: Chad Wolf Takes Over as Acting DHS Secretary
summary: Trump administration's pick for temporary post is expected to elevate Ken Cuccinelli to No. 2 job at the department. WASHINGTON-Chad Wolf was sworn in as acting Secretary of Homeland Security after being confirmed by the Senate to an undersecretary role on Wednesday, putting him atop the agency's line of succession.

title: Temperatures Are Falling, and so Are Heating Costs
summary: Winter weather has arrived, but heating fuels are priced like Americans still have their windows open. Winter weather has arrived, blanketing much of the country in snow and freezing temperatures. But heating fuels are priced like Americans still have their windows open.

title: Colleges Can Be Forced to Return Tuition When Parents Go Bankrupt
summary: A federal appeals court ruling exposes colleges to lawsuits from bankruptcy trustees seeking to pay creditors. Colleges can be forced to return tuition payments made for students whose parents can't cover their own debts, according to a federal appeals court ruling that opens up higher education institutions to more litigation in bankruptcy courts.

title: The Politics Behind Colin Kaepernick's NFL Workout
summary: The league's decision to stage the unusual showcase has been met with skepticism and comes after his absence of opportunity had become a growing source of frustration. Whenever NFL commissioner Roger Goodell has been asked why Colin Kaepernick remains unsigned after nearly three years, his answer has always been the same: Don't ask me, ask the teams. The NFL, he has stressed, doesn't get involved in player personnel decisions.

title: Gaza Rocket Attacks on Israel Resume, Risking Wider Conflict
summary: The strikes are complicating efforts to form a new coalition government. TEL AVIV-Militants in Gaza fired rockets into Israel for the second straight day, raising the risk of a wider conflict as Israel continued its own strikes on the second-largest armed group operating in the Palestinian enclave.

title: U.S. Budget Gap Hits $1 Trillion Over Past 12 Months
summary: Deficit widened 34% to $134 billion in October. WASHINGTON-The U.S. budget gap grew 34% in the first month of the fiscal year as federal spending outpaced revenue growth, pushing the 12-month deficit past $1 trillion for the first time since February 2013.

title: Coach's Designer on Acing Holiday Gift-Giving
summary: Stuart Vevers, the brand's creative director since 2013, describes his current obsessions and Christmas plans. THIS YEAR, Coach will become the first luxury fashion brand to have a float in Macy'sThanksgiving Day Parade. For anyone who's followed the label since Stuart Vevers took over in 2013, there's really no question as to what form it will take: Rexy, of course, the campily ferocious T. rex who's now as much a part of the Coach lexicon as the New York brand's turn-lock handbag closures.

title: Chip Makers Push Spending to the Extreme
summary: Demand for 'extreme ultraviolet' gear and related tools fuels a surge in capital expenditures. Chip makers are seeing the light. And it is costing them.

title: Venice Flooded With Second-Highest Waters on Record
summary: As floods hit St. Mark's Basilica, shops and restaurants, residents grumble over delayed protection. VENICE, Italy-Davide Pontini has seen his share of floods here in his native city. But the one this week shocked him as the tide rose to the second-highest level since records began 150 years ago, inundating swaths of the city that normally stay dry and adding to anxiety about Venice's long-term future.

title: Auto Borrowing Rises Amid Low Interest Rates, Solid Economy
summary: Increase includes growth in loans with terms longer than six years as Americans stretch to afford higher car prices. WASHINGTON-Americans are borrowing more for cars, a sign lower interest rates and a decadelong economic expansion are supporting purchases of large household items.

title: Justice Department Filing Suggests No McCabe Prosecution Imminent
summary: In pending lawsuit, DOJ says it won't block release of documents related to former deputy FBI head based on probe. The Justice Department suggested in a filing Wednesday that it had no immediate plans to prosecute former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, saying it would no longer try to keep documents related to Mr. McCabe from being publicly released because of an ongoing enforcement proceeding.

title: Abbott Labs CEO to Step Down
summary: Current president, Robert Ford, will replace him; Mr. White will remain as chairman. Abbott Laboratories said Chief Executive Miles D. White, who oversaw the transformation of the health-care-products maker with a series of acquisitions and spinoffs in more than 20 years at the helm, will step down as CEO in March 2020.

summary: Resume Subscription. Weimar and Dessau, Germany

title: Fed's Powell Signals Comfort With Current Interest-Rate Stance
summary: Central bank chairman calls on policy makers to address rising deficits so Congress can better counteract a future downturn. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell told lawmakers the central bank saw little need to cut interest rates further after making three reductions since July.

title: A Guide to What to Watch on Disney+ Right Now
summary: From 'The Mandalorian' to 'Cinderella,' highlights of movies and series streaming on the new platform. For all the buzz surrounding the launch of Disney+ there are only so many hours in the day to consume the nearly 500 films and 7,500 TV episodes streaming on the new service.

title: Superbugs Toll Worse Than Thought, CDC Says
summary: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria and fungi have spread beyond hospitals, complicating medical care, new CDC report says. Drug-resistant bacteria and fungi, along with heavy use of antibiotics, fuel nearly 3.1 million infections with 48,700 deaths every year in the U.S., according to a new federal report warning that the toll from so-called superbugs is greater than previously known.

title: Did ABC and CBS Collude to Punish the Wrong Employee?
summary: Being suspected of whistleblowing may be enough to get fired by broadcast networks.. On Thursday this column noted that while news organizations ABC and CBS publicly revere the holy sanctity of anonymity for the federal "whistleblower," they collaborated to identify and fire their own suspected whistleblower. But they seem to have axed the wrong employee. And now a new report suggests that ABC is back on the hunt for its internal dissenter.

title: 'Our Pathetic Age' by DJ Shadow Review: A Case for Pushing Boundaries
summary: A long record with a loose theme about how society has lost its way in the time of media saturation and the collapse of truth sees the artist moving outside his comfort zone..

title: These Soups Will Make You a Better Cook
summary: In his new cookbook 'The New Orleans Kitchen,' chef Justin Devillier makes the case that soups provide an ideal entry point to his city's cuisine and a solid grounding in culinary techniques. IT BREAKS MY HEART, as a lifelong soup aficionado, to see soup get no respect. Lazy chefs all too often treat the stockpot like a graveyard, throwing in random kitchen scraps and hoping for the best. Those bowls invariably wind up muddled, with indistinguishable bits of sodden vegetables and stringy meat, or worse yet, puréed to the consistency of baby food.

title: A Look at the Original Waldorf-Astoria
summary: The hotel was a combination of two grand hotels located on Fifth Avenue. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: IEA Sees U.S. Shale Squeezing OPEC Influence

U.S. shale-oil production will reshape global energy markets in the years to come, bolstering the country's influence over OPEC nations, the International Energy Agency said Wednesday.

title: Gas Prices Drive October Inflation Increase
summary: New tariffs on imports appear to have little effect on prices for apparel, household furnishings. WASHINGTON-Gasoline costs pushed up prices for U.S. consumer goods in October, while new tariffs on imports appeared to have little effect on what Americans paid for clothing and household furnishings.

title: Nike to Stop Selling Directly to Amazon
summary: Sportswear giant's decision is blow to Amazon's effort to court big brands. Nike Inc. said it would stop selling its clothes and sneakers directly to Amazon.com Inc., an about-face for the sportswear brand.

title: Fed Adds $77.09 Billion to Markets as Powell Affirms Liquidity Operation
summary: Additions include $67.84 billion in Treasurys and $9.25 billion in mortgage-backed securities. The New York Fed added $77.09 billion in liquidity to financial markets on Wednesday, on a day where the U.S. central bank leader again affirmed that the operation and ones like it don't have any implications for the broader economy.

title: New York City Awards $5.3 Million in Contracts to Nonprofit That Owes State
summary: Institute for the Puerto Rican/Hispanic Elderly is affiliated with Acacia Network and is alleged to have misused grants intended for crime victims. New York City officials recently gave $5.3 million in contracts to a nonprofit that owes the state $143,678 for allegedly misusing grant money.

title: Inside a Chinese Developer's Nearly $3 Billion Bet on the Storied Waldorf Astoria
summary: Frank Sinatra once paid $1 million a year for a suite at the hotel. Now its new owner is banking on the hotel's glamorous past to sell luxury condos.. When the 47-story Waldorf Astoria hotel opened on New York's Park Avenue in 1931, it was the tallest hotel in the world. With a radio in every one of its 2,200 suites, in-room dining and "manufactured weather" (the term then for air-conditioning), it was also the most luxurious of its time. Its opening was such an event that on Sept. 30 of that year, President Herbert Hoover delivered a radio address to mark the occasion, congratulating the builders and forecasting a new era of growth and prosperity for the country.

title: Composers Who Found Inspiration in the Vernacular
summary: Michael Tilson Thomas and the San Francisco Symphony offer a new recording of Charles Ives music; violinist Rachel Barton Pine plays concertos by Antonín Dvořák and Aram Khachaturian..

title: The Fed Gives Investors a Green Light
summary: With the Federal Reserve unlikely to tighten until inflation gets a lot warmer, rates could stay low. The only thing that seems likely to get the Federal Reserve to raise rates again is a lot more inflation. Until that happens, it will be giving investors a green light to buy stocks and other risky assets. Similar occasions have had very unhappy endings.

title: Luckin Coffee Sales Rise Sixfold
summary: Tea launch weighs on expenses; company's loss widens. Shares of Luckin Coffee Inc. rose roughly 14% on Wednesday after the Beijing-based coffee chain's revenue soared as it added stores and expanded its offerings beyond coffee.

title: The Tour's 'Eternal Second' Raymond Poulidor, Dies at Age 83
summary: Poulidor was a rare professional athlete to earn the adoration of millions precisely for his failures; a cycling legend who never wore the Tour's yellow jersey. PARIS-Raymond Poulidor, the affable French cyclist whose career of dramatic narrow losses at the Tour de France made him a national darling but never a Tour champion, died on Wednesday. He was 83.

title: Small Town in Georgia Has Big Plans for an Enormous Chicken
summary: Hoping to feather its nest and scratch up some tourism, a community is trying to build the world's tallest topiary sculpture; 'It's something different'. FITZGERALD, Ga.-Mayor Jim Puckett's dream rises next to a supermarket parking lot.

title: Tencent Earnings Drop 13% as Rivals Intrude on Advertising Territory
summary: Tech giant is wrestling with younger contenders like Bytedance, whose short-video apps TikTok and Douyin have won a global audience. Tencent Holdings Ltd. 's profit slid in the third quarter as the Chinese tech giant looked to expand its gaming business abroad while grappling with upstart tech rivals and slowing economic growth at home.

title: Cracking Open the Great Lobster Arbitrage Trade

Lobster exports to China are among the trade flows that have been hammered by the trade war that escalated in mid-2018. U.S. lobster sales to the Middle Kingdom, running at nearly $90 million in the first half of 2018, plummeted to just $19 million a year later, after China imposed a 25% tariff on America exports of the shellfish delicacy. China turned to Canadian crustaceans instead.

title: Beyond Bling: The Over-The-Top History of Gold Teeth
summary: Sparkling smiles aren't quite as contemporary as they appear. AL SMITH, New York's governor in the 1920s, had teeth "capped with gold," according to Robert Caro's "The Power Broker." Dr. Ruchi Sahota, a dentist in Fremont, Calif., explained that gilded canines and incisors like Mr. Smith's were common throughout the early- to mid-20th century. "Gold was used very, very often," for routine dental procedures. Her own 60-something mother has both a gold crown and a gold filling. Duller materials-tin, copper and mercury-were also used, but gold always stood out. A single gold crown in the back of your jaw goes unnoticed, but men like Mr. Smith with a full slate of gilded chompers made a fashion statement with every grin.

title: Sweden to Abandon Negative Rates, but Currency Can't Catch a Break
summary: The Swedish krona is the worst performer among major nations' currencies since 2018, and remains susceptible to global trade tensions. Sweden, unlike most of the rest of the slow-growth world, has had enough of negative interest rates.

title: Mass-Shooting Study Raises Questions on Security Efforts
summary: Perpetrators at schools and workplaces are typically insiders who know safety procedures, study finds.
